repnme.cdata!:
St. Kitts and Nevis - Emergency Recovery
            and Disaster Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, with substantial
            institutional development impacts, and satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. Lessons specific
            to St. Kitts and Nevis suggest that projects like this one,
            can bring disaster management into the mainstream, not just
            through implementation of works and procurement of disaster
            supplies, but through consistent supervision, and
            consciousness raising. Lessons relevant to emergency
            operations as a whole suggest priority in this type of
            projects, should be given to prevention, immediate measures
            to reactivate economic activity, and careful assessment of
            longer-term reconstruction priorities and designs; that it
            would have been preferable to process the various
            loans/credits for the different OECS countries, as separate
            projects, part of a broader program, but not integrated into
            one horizontal APL; that careful attention should be given
            to the project unit manpower, particularly given local
            capacity constraints; that terms of reference for consulting
            engineers, should specify government budget constraints to
            avoid unaffordable infrastructure, while the Bank should
            also require performance guarantees of consultants, and
            apply penalties for late submissions, as needed.

repnme.cdata!:
Organization of Eastern Caribbean States
            (OECS) - Emergency Recovery and Disaster Management Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Program Project for the countries comprising the
            Organization of Eastern Caribbean States--St. Kitts &
            Nevis, St. Lucia, Dominica, Grenada, and St. Vincent &
            the Grenadines--will finance lending operations in each of
            the five mentioned countries with the objects of 1)
            fortifying, or reconstructing and rehabilitating key
            economic and social infrastructure and facilities to
            minimize damage or disruption caused by future natural and
            man-made disasters and to speed emergency recovery following
            such disasters; and 2) strengthening the countries'
            institutional capacities to prepare for and respond to
            disaster emergencies efficiently and effectively. Assistance
            to St. Kitts & Nevis consists in particular of a fast
            disbursing loan for essential imports. The countries are
            aided in rebuilding and rehabilitating infrastructure
            related to hospitals, shelters, water supply, electricity,
            roads and coastal protection, and airports, thereby
            restoring public services. Similarly, the five countries are
            helped in strengthening their emergency preparedness and
            response systems; and in training, technology, and equipment
            for institutional strengthening.
